Biochemistry.name: Alanine Aminotransferase (ALT)
Biochemistry.overview: ALT is a liver enzyme highly specific for hepatocellular injury; elevated in hepatitis, fatty liver, or drug toxicity.

Biochemistry.name: Aspartate Aminotransferase (AST)
Biochemistry.overview: AST is found in liver, heart, and muscle; less specific than ALT but useful in alcoholic liver disease when AST:ALT >2.
Biochemistry.procedure: Enzyme indicating cellular damage in liver, heart, or muscle

Biochemistry.name: Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP)
Biochemistry.overview: ALP is elevated in cholestasis or biliary obstruction; also increased in bone diseases like Paget’s.
Biochemistry.procedure: Enzyme elevated in cholestasis or bone disorders

Biochemistry.name: Gamma-Glutamyl Transferase (GGT)
Biochemistry.overview: GGT is a sensitive marker for alcohol use and cholestatic liver disease; helps confirm hepatic origin of elevated ALP.
Biochemistry.procedure: Sensitive marker for cholestasis and alcohol use

Biochemistry.name: Total Bilirubin
Biochemistry.overview: Total bilirubin measures heme breakdown; elevated in hemolysis, hepatitis, or obstruction.
Biochemistry.procedure: Measures breakdown product of heme metabolism

Biochemistry.name: Direct Bilirubin
Biochemistry.overview: Direct bilirubin indicates cholestasis or impaired bile excretion by the liver.

Biochemistry.name: Indirect Bilirubin
Biochemistry.overview: Indirect bilirubin suggests hemolysis or impaired conjugation such as Gilbert syndrome.

Biochemistry.name: Albumin
Biochemistry.overview: Albumin reflects the liver’s synthetic function; low levels indicate chronic liver disease or malnutrition.
Biochemistry.procedure: Protein synthesized by the liver; reflects synthetic function

Biochemistry.name: Total Protein
Biochemistry.overview: Total protein includes albumin and globulins; low in liver disease or malnutrition, high in dehydration or chronic inflammation.
Biochemistry.procedure: Sum of albumin and all globulin fractions

Biochemistry.name: Globulin
Biochemistry.overview: Globulin fraction includes antibodies and transport proteins; calculated as Total Protein minus Albumin.

Biochemistry.name: Albumin/Globulin Ratio (A/G Ratio)
Biochemistry.overview: A/G ratio helps differentiate causes of abnormal protein levels; low in chronic liver disease or multiple myeloma.
Biochemistry.procedure: Calculated as Albumin divided by Globulin

Biochemistry.name: Prothrombin Time (PT)
Biochemistry.overview: PT assesses liver synthetic function and vitamin K status.
Biochemistry.procedure: Clotting test dependent on liver-synthesized factors

Biochemistry.name: INR
Biochemistry.overview: INR standardizes PT results for anticoagulation monitoring.

Biochemistry.name: Serum Creatinine
Biochemistry.overview: Serum creatinine is a key marker of kidney function; used to estimate GFR.
Biochemistry.procedure: Waste product filtered by glomeruli; reflects GFR

Biochemistry.name: Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN)
Biochemistry.overview: BUN reflects nitrogen waste from protein metabolism; influenced by renal, GI, and hydration status.

Biochemistry.name: eGFR
Biochemistry.overview: eGFR estimates kidney filtration rate; critical for staging chronic kidney disease.
Biochemistry.sample: Calculated from serum creatinine, age, sex, race

Biochemistry.name: Cystatin C
Biochemistry.overview: Cystatin C is a sensitive marker of early kidney dysfunction.
Biochemistry.procedure: Protein filtered by kidneys; less affected by muscle mass

Biochemistry.name: Uric Acid
Biochemistry.overview: Uric acid is the end product of purine metabolism; elevated in gout or tumor lysis.

Biochemistry.name: Microalbuminuria (Urine Albumin-to-Creatinine Ratio)
Biochemistry.overview: Microalbuminuria is an early marker of diabetic nephropathy and endothelial dysfunction.
Biochemistry.procedure: Measures small amounts of albumin in urine; ratio to creatinine corrects for concentration

Biochemistry.name: Creatinine Clearance
Biochemistry.overview: Creatinine clearance provides a direct measure of GFR using 24-hour urine collection.
Biochemistry.procedure: Calculated as (Urine Cr × Urine volume) / (Serum Cr × 1440 min)

Biochemistry.name: Random Urine Creatinine
Biochemistry.overview: Used to normalize other urine analytes (e.g., albumin, protein) in spot samples.
Biochemistry.procedure: Concentration varies with hydration; used for ratios

Biochemistry.name: Total Cholesterol
Biochemistry.overview: Total cholesterol is a cardiovascular risk marker; elevated in hyperlipidemia or hypothyroidism.

Biochemistry.name: LDL Cholesterol
Biochemistry.overview: LDL is 'bad cholesterol'; primary target for atherosclerosis prevention.

Biochemistry.name: HDL Cholesterol
Biochemistry.overview: HDL is 'good cholesterol'; protective against cardiovascular disease.

Biochemistry.name: Triglycerides
Biochemistry.overview: Triglycerides reflect energy storage; elevated in obesity, diabetes, or alcohol use.
Biochemistry.procedure: Fats stored in adipose tissue and used for energy

Biochemistry.name: Non-HDL Cholesterol
Biochemistry.overview: Non-HDL cholesterol represents all atherogenic lipoproteins and is calculated as total cholesterol minus HDL.

Biochemistry.name: Troponin I
Biochemistry.overview: Troponin I is highly specific for myocardial injury; gold standard for MI diagnosis.

Biochemistry.name: CK-MB
Biochemistry.overview: CK-MB is a cardiac-specific isoenzyme; useful for detecting reinfarction.

Biochemistry.name: BNP
Biochemistry.overview: BNP is a hormone released from cardiac ventricles in response to increased wall stress.

Biochemistry.name: NT-proBNP
Biochemistry.overview: NT-proBNP is an inactive fragment released along with BNP and is used to assess heart failure.

Biochemistry.name: Myoglobin
Biochemistry.overview: Myoglobin rises within 1–2 hours of myocardial injury; early but non-specific marker.

Biochemistry.name: LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase)
Biochemistry.overview: LDH is a non-specific marker of tissue damage; elevated in hemolysis, liver disease, or malignancy.

Biochemistry.name: Homocysteine
Biochemistry.overview: Elevated homocysteine is a risk factor for thrombosis and cardiovascular disease.

Biochemistry.name: Fasting Blood Glucose
Biochemistry.overview: Fasting blood glucose is the primary test for diabetes screening and diagnosis.

Biochemistry.name: Random Blood Glucose
Biochemistry.overview: Random glucose is used for symptomatic hyperglycemia assessment without fasting.
Biochemistry.procedure: Glucose measured at any time of day

Biochemistry.name: Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT)
Biochemistry.overview: OGTT diagnoses impaired glucose tolerance and gestational diabetes.
Biochemistry.procedure: Measures glucose response after 75g glucose load

Biochemistry.name: Hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c)
Biochemistry.overview: HbA1c reflects average blood glucose over the past 2–3 months; used for diabetes monitoring.

Biochemistry.name: Insulin
Biochemistry.overview: Insulin level assesses endogenous insulin production; used in hypoglycemia workup.

Biochemistry.name: C-Peptide
Biochemistry.overview: C-peptide reflects endogenous insulin secretion; useful when exogenous insulin is used.

Biochemistry.name: Fructosamine
Biochemistry.overview: Fructosamine reflects average glucose over 2–3 weeks; useful when HbA1c is unreliable.

Biochemistry.name: Amylase
Biochemistry.overview: Amylase is elevated in acute pancreatitis and salivary gland disorders.

Biochemistry.name: Lipase
Biochemistry.overview: Lipase is more specific than amylase for acute pancreatitis and remains elevated longer.

Biochemistry.name: TSH
Biochemistry.overview: TSH is the most sensitive test for thyroid dysfunction; regulated by pituitary-thyroid feedback.

Biochemistry.name: Free T4
Biochemistry.overview: Free T4 is the active thyroid hormone; used with TSH to assess thyroid status.

Biochemistry.name: Free T3
Biochemistry.overview: Free T3 is the most biologically active thyroid hormone; elevated in T3-toxicosis.

Biochemistry.name: Anti-TPO Antibodies
Biochemistry.overview: Anti-TPO antibodies indicate autoimmune thyroid disease such as Hashimoto thyroiditis.

Biochemistry.name: Cortisol
Biochemistry.overview: Cortisol is the main stress hormone; abnormal levels indicate adrenal disorders.

Biochemistry.name: ACTH
Biochemistry.overview: ACTH stimulates cortisol production; helps differentiate primary vs. secondary adrenal insufficiency.

Biochemistry.name: Aldosterone
Biochemistry.overview: Aldosterone regulates sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion.

Biochemistry.name: Renin Activity
Biochemistry.overview: Renin activity helps diagnose secondary hyperaldosteronism.

Biochemistry.name: Testosterone
Biochemistry.overview: Testosterone is the primary male sex hormone; imbalances affect fertility and secondary sex characteristics.

Biochemistry.name: Estradiol
Biochemistry.overview: Estradiol is the main estrogen; important in female reproductive health and bone density.

Biochemistry.name: Progesterone
Biochemistry.overview: Progesterone prepares the endometrium for pregnancy; peaks in luteal phase.

Biochemistry.name: Prolactin
Biochemistry.overview: Prolactin regulates milk production; elevated in prolactinoma or medications.

Biochemistry.name: Parathyroid Hormone (PTH)
Biochemistry.overview: PTH increases serum calcium and decreases phosphate.

Biochemistry.name: Ionized Calcium
Biochemistry.overview: Ionized calcium is the physiologically active form; more accurate than total calcium.
high_conditions: Same as total calcium, but unaffected by albumin
low_conditions: Same as total calcium, but more reliable in hypoalbuminemia

Biochemistry.name: Total Calcium
Biochemistry.overview: Calcium is regulated by PTH and vitamin D; important for bones, nerves, and muscles.
Biochemistry.procedure: Mineral regulated by PTH and vitamin D

Biochemistry.name: Phosphorus
Biochemistry.overview: Phosphorus is essential for ATP, bones, and cell membranes.

Biochemistry.name: CEA
Biochemistry.overview: CEA is a tumor marker for colorectal cancer; also elevated in smoking or inflammation.
Biochemistry.procedure: Marker for colorectal and other cancers

Biochemistry.name: AFP
Biochemistry.overview: AFP is elevated in hepatocellular carcinoma and germ cell tumors; also in liver regeneration.
Biochemistry.procedure: Marker for hepatocellular carcinoma and germ cell tumors

Biochemistry.name: CA 19-9
Biochemistry.overview: CA 19-9 is used for pancreatic and biliary tract cancers; also elevated in benign obstruction.
Biochemistry.procedure: Marker for pancreatic and biliary cancers

Biochemistry.name: PSA
Biochemistry.overview: PSA screens for prostate cancer; also elevated in benign prostatic hyperplasia.
Biochemistry.procedure: Screening and monitoring for prostate cancer

Biochemistry.name: CA-125
Biochemistry.overview: CA-125 is primarily used for ovarian cancer monitoring and endometriosis.

Biochemistry.name: CA 15-3
Biochemistry.overview: CA 15-3 is used to monitor breast cancer progression and recurrence.

Biochemistry.name: Beta-hCG
Biochemistry.overview: Beta-hCG is the pregnancy hormone; also elevated in gestational trophoblastic disease.

Biochemistry.name: Vitamin D (25-hydroxyvitamin D)
Biochemistry.overview: Vitamin D (25-OH) is the best indicator of vitamin D status; deficiency causes rickets/osteomalacia.

Biochemistry.name: Vitamin B12
Biochemistry.overview: Vitamin B12 is essential for DNA synthesis and nerve function; deficiency causes megaloblastic anemia.

Biochemistry.name: Folate
Biochemistry.overview: Folate (vitamin B9) deficiency leads to megaloblastic anemia and neural tube defects.

Biochemistry.name: Vitamin A (Retinol)
Biochemistry.overview: Vitamin A deficiency causes night blindness and immune dysfunction.

Biochemistry.name: Vitamin E (Alpha-Tocopherol)
Biochemistry.overview: Vitamin E deficiency can cause hemolytic anemia, neurological deficits, and muscle weakness.

Biochemistry.name: Vitamin K Status (PT / PIVKA-II)
Biochemistry.overview: Vitamin K status is assessed by PT and PIVKA-II; deficiency impairs clotting factor synthesis.
Biochemistry.procedure: PT and PIVKA-II reflect vitamin K-dependent clotting factors

Biochemistry.name: Ferritin
Biochemistry.overview: Ferritin reflects iron stores; low in iron deficiency, high in inflammation or hemochromatosis.

Biochemistry.name: Transferrin Saturation
Biochemistry.overview: Transferrin saturation assesses iron availability; low in iron deficiency, high in hemochromatosis.

Biochemistry.name: Sodium (Na⁺)
Biochemistry.overview: Sodium is the main extracellular cation; critical for fluid balance and neurological function.

Biochemistry.name: Potassium (K⁺)
Biochemistry.overview: Potassium is essential for cardiac and neuromuscular function; abnormalities can be life-threatening.
Biochemistry.procedure: Key intracellular cation; critical for cardiac function

Biochemistry.name: Chloride (Cl⁻)
Biochemistry.overview: Chloride maintains electroneutrality and acid-base balance.

Biochemistry.name: Bicarbonate (HCO₃⁻)
Biochemistry.overview: Bicarbonate is a key buffer in acid-base balance; part of the anion gap calculation.

Biochemistry.name: Magnesium
Biochemistry.overview: Magnesium is a cofactor for hundreds of enzymes; deficiency causes neuromuscular irritability.

Biochemistry.name: Zinc
Biochemistry.overview: Zinc is essential for immune function and wound healing; deficiency causes dermatitis and diarrhea.

Biochemistry.name: Copper / Ceruloplasmin
Biochemistry.overview: Copper and ceruloplasmin are measured to assess copper status; low in Wilson disease.

Biochemistry.name: Selenium
Biochemistry.overview: Selenium deficiency can lead to cardiomyopathy (Keshan disease) and impaired antioxidant defense.

Biochemistry.name: Iodine (Urinary)
Biochemistry.overview: Iodine status is assessed by urinary iodine concentration.
